title: The first space walk
intro: Remember to subscribe to the podcast version !
this_week_question: How long did the first space walk last? Was it... a) 2 minutes? b) 12 minutes? c) 22 minutes?
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: left somewhere with no way of leaving
a place where nobody had ever visited
being able to make good decisions or act quickly in a difficult situation
twist or squeeze something to remove water

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Rob…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: … and I'm Neil. Hello.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hello, Neil! I watched that space movie last night – the one where those astronauts are stranded in space.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Stranded means stuck in a place with only a small chance of leaving. Gravity , you mean?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: That's the one. And this year marks the 50th anniversary of the first ever space walk. On 18th March 1965 Russian cosmonaut Alexei Leonov was the first man to drift free in space – 500km from the surface of Earth. And that’s the subject of today’s show!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: What on earth must that have felt like?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Ah ha! Exactly. It would have felt like nothing on earth – and that’s to say, very strange indeed. He was the first person to experience the colourful geography of our planet stretched out before him.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Very poetic, Rob! But moving on, how about answering today’s quiz question: How long did the first space walk last? Was it...

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Hmm. All quite short – so I think I’ll go for the one in the middle – 12 minutes.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: We'll find out if you're right or wrong later on. Now, ‘cosmonaut’ literally means ‘sailor of the universe’. But Leonov’s mission wasn’t plain sailing – in other words, it wasn’t easy or straightforward.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: That’s right.  No one had ever gone out into space before – it was unknown territory – unknown territory means a place or activity that people do not know anything about or have not experienced before. And as it happens, there were big problems.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: When Leonov left the capsule his spacesuit inflated – or swelled up – like a balloon because the pressure inside the suit was greater than outside.  This made it impossible for Leonov to get back through the door of the spacecraft, putting him in a life-threatening situation.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Let’s listen to Helen Sharman, the first Briton in space, talking about it.

transcript.author: Helen Sharman, first Briton in space
transcript.text: So he decreases the pressure of his suit, which means that it’s a bit more able to move inside it, but it means the amount of oxygen he’s got around his face is now dangerously low so he can’t cope with that for very long. So if he’s not able to get in quickly, he’s going to die of oxygen starvation, um […] so he had the presence of mind to get on with all of this, got back in, swivelled himself round, managed to close the airlock, and then when the pressure was equilibrated was finally able to, you know, hug his compatriot up there in space.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Now, if you can’t cope with something it means you are unable to deal successfully with a difficult situation. And here the situation was having very little oxygen.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: But Leonov had the presence of mind to find a solution. Presence of mind means being able to react quickly and stay calm in a difficult or dangerous situation.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And if I was in Leonov’s shoes – meaning if I was in his situation – I would have panicked big time!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And there was plenty more to panic about before the mission was over. The spacecraft’s automatic re-entry system failed so the cosmonauts had to fire the rockets manually – meaning controlled by hand – which they had never done before.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And that’s not all. Their capsule failed to detach – or separate – from the spacecraft’s equipment module, and this sent them tumbling through space towards Earth.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: But the capsule did finally detach. And then you would think they’d have been home and dry, wouldn’t you? Home and dry means being close to achieving a goal.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, they certainly weren’t dry. The capsule touched down – or landed – hundreds of kilometres off course in freezing Siberia populated only by wolves and bears. Leonov had sweated so much on the space walk that his boots were filled with water up to his knees! Both cosmonauts had to wring out – or twist and squeeze – their clothes to avoid frostbite.

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: And off course , by the way, means not following the right route. Those men must have been overjoyed when they were finally airlifted to safety two days later!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But what seems unfair to me is, we all know about the Apollo moon landing, but how many of us know about the first space walk?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Well, at least we do now, and of course our listeners do too!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK, let’s have the answer to the quiz question. I asked: How long did the first space walk last? Was it… a) 2 minutes b) 12 minutes or c) 22 minutes?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: I said a) 12 minutes.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And you were right!

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: Excellent. Good! So 12 minutes eh? What an amazing short stroll that must have been but a very historic one too.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well done. Now, can we hear today’s words again please?

transcript.author: Rob
transcript.text: OK. We heard:

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, that’s the end of today's 6 Minute English. We thought it was out of this world – hope you thought so too! Please join us again soon.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye.

authors: Helen Sharman, first Briton in space
